{{Infobox person |name = Bobby Dekeyser |image = 4087Unternehmer und Ex-Fußballprofi Bobby Dekeyser.JPG |caption = Dekeyser on ''Markus Lanz'' ([[ZDF]]), 2012 |birth_name = Robert Dekeyser |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1964|10|7|df=yes}} |birth_place = [[Leuven]], [[Belgium]] |residence = [[Hamburg]], [[Germany]] |height = {{convert|1.86|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |occupation = Entrepreneur (founder of {{Interlanguage link multi|DEDON|de}}; former professional footballer |years active = 1980–1991 (footballer), 1990–present (entrepreneur) |spouse = Ann-Kathrin Dekeyser (−2010) |children = Carolin, Yannik, Marie |module = {{Infobox football biography | embed = yes | header-color = #B0C4DE | position = [[Goalkeeper (association football)|Goalkeeper]] | youthyears1 = | youthclubs1 = [[Oud-Heverlee Leuven]] | youthyears2 = {{0|0000}}–1980 | youthclubs2 = [[Wormatia Worms]] | youthyears3 = 1980–1982 | youthclubs3 = [[1. FC Kaiserslautern]] | years1 = 1984–1986 | clubs1 = [[Union Saint-Gilloise]] | caps1 = | goals1 = 0 | years2 = 1986–1987 | clubs2 = [[FC Bayern Munich|Bayern Munich]] | caps2 = 0 | goals2 = 0 | years3 = 1987–1988 | clubs3 = [[1. FC Nürnberg]] | caps3 = 0 | goals3 = 0 | years4 = 1988–1989 | clubs4 = [[KRC Genk]] | caps4 = 2 | goals4 = 0 | years5 = 1989–1992 | clubs5 = [[TSV 1860 Munich|1860 Munich]] | caps5 = 19 | goals5 = 0 | totalcaps = | totalgoals = 0 }} }}
'''Robert Dekeyser''' (born 7 October 1964) is a Belgian-German [[entrepreneur]] and former [[Association football|football]] [[Goalkeeper (football)|goalkeeper]].<ref name='BobbyBook'>{{cite book | url = http://www.ankerherz.de/produkte/unverkaeuflich/ | title = Unverkäuflich: Schulabbrecher, Fussballprofi, Weltunternehmer | trans-title = Not for Sale: School Dropout, Professional Footballer, Global Entrepreneur | first1 = Bobby | last1 = Dekeyser | first2 = Stefan | last2 = Krücken | publisher = Ankerherz Verlag | date = 1 May 2012 | pages = 208 | isbn = 978-3-940138-21-7 | language = German | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120809053258/http://www.ankerherz.de/produkte/unverkaeuflich/ | archivedate = 9 August 2012 | df = dmy-all }}</ref> He is the founder of {{Interlanguage link multi|DEDON|de}}, a Germany-based manufacturer of [[outdoor furniture]] with distribution in more than 80 countries.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.minimalhome.com/category/DEDON,b.html | title = MinimalHome: The Home of Modern Minimal Living | publisher = minimalhome.com | accessdate = 17 November 2012 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120617190544/http://www.minimalhome.com/category/DEDON,b.html | archivedate = 17 June 2012 | df = dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www1.philstar.com/lifestyle/modern-living/602425/german-furniture-proudly-made-in-cebu | archive-url = https://archive.is/20130208162816/http://www1.philstar.com/lifestyle/modern-living/602425/german-furniture-proudly-made-in-cebu | dead-url = yes | archive-date = 8 February 2013 | title = German furniture, proudly made in Cebu | publisher = The Philippine Star | date = 14 August 2010 | accessdate = 16 November 2012 | first = Joy Angelica | last = Subido }}</ref> An outdoor enthusiast, Dekeyser is also the founder of DEDON ISLAND, a luxury resort in the [[Philippines]].<ref name ='BobbyBook'/><ref name ='FA'>{{cite web | url = http://www.faz.net/aktuell/beruf-chance/mein-weg/robert-dekeyser-er-kann-nur-angreifen-11555129.html | title = Robert Dekeyser: Er kann nur angreifen |trans-title=Robert Dekeyser: He can only attack | language = German | publisher = FrankfurterAllgemeine | accessdate = 16 November 2012 | first = Peter-Philipp | last = Schmitt | date = 8 December 2011}}</ref><ref name ='Vogue'>{{cite news | title = Der menschliche Faktor |trans-title=The Human Factor | first = Robert | last = Ehmich | newspaper = [[Vogue (magazine)|VOGUE]] Deutschland | date = June 2012 | pages = 206–219 | language = German}}</ref>
==Early life== Dekeyser was born in [[Leuven]], Belgium, the eldest son of entrepreneurs who divorced when he was young.<ref name ='BobbyBook'/><ref name ='DedonBobby'>{{cite web | url = http://www.dedon.de/en/company/bobby-dekeyser.html | title = Bobby Dekeyser | publisher = DEDON | accessdate = 17 November 2012}}</ref> Raised in [[Belgium]], [[Austria]] and [[Germany]], he recalls his childhood as "chaotic", leaving him with a deep-seated longing for harmony.<ref name ='BobbyBook'/><ref name ='Welt'>{{cite web | url = https://www.welt.de/vermischtes/prominente/article106350569/Das-neue-Leben-des-gescheiterten-Bayern-Torwarts.html | title = Das neue Leben des gescheiterten Bayern-Torwarts |trans-title=The new life of a failed Bayern Goalkeeper | language = German | publisher = Welt Online | date = 21 May 2012 | accessdate = 16 November 2012 | first = Inga | last = Griese}}</ref> A self-described rebel and school truant, he turned to football as a source of discipline and self-esteem.<ref name ='DedonBobby'/><ref name ='D&F'>[http://dfacademy.org/about/bobby 'Bobby', ''D&F Academy: About Us'']</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://dfacademy.org/about/bobby | title = Just follow your Dreams! | publisher = D&F Academy | accessdate = 17 November 2012}}</ref> At 14, he won a talent contest, earning himself a place at the [[New York City|New York]] soccer camp of his idol, the Brazilian striker [[Pelé]], whom he credits with encouraging him to "follow your dreams".<ref name ='BobbyBook'/><ref name ='D&F'/><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.zeit.de/2012/07/P-Dekeyser | title = Möbelfabrikant Bobby Dekeyser: Gefühl statt Kalkül |trans-title=Furniture-maker Bobby Dekeyser: Sensation instead of Calculation | language = German | publisher = Die Zeit | date = 14 February 2012 | accessdate = 16 November 2012 | first = Jens | last = Tönnesmann}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.zdf.de/ZDF/zdfportal/programdata/e6945324-1cb6-3c02-8b90-3874ee0f4b2d/7953972?noDispatch=1 | title = Markus Lanz | language = German | publisher = ZDF | date = 23 May 2012 | accessdate = 16 November 2012}}</ref> At the age of 15, having attended nine different schools, Dekeyser stood up in English class and announced that he was dropping out to become a professional footballer.<ref name ='BobbyBook'/><ref name ='FA'/><ref name ='DedonBobby'/><ref name='DW'>{{cite web|url=http://www.dw.de/dw/episode/0,,5292781,00.html |title=Talking Germany—The German Way of Life: Presenter Peter Caven talks to Bobby Dekeyser about dreams, fast-track school leaving exams and goalkeepers |publisher=Deutsche Welle |date=15 March 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131004232059/http://www.dw.de/dw/episode/0,,5292781,00.html |archivedate=4 October 2013 }}</ref>
==Football career== In 1980, at the age of 16, Dekeyser joined the Junior A-League team [[1. FC Kaiserslautern]] as goalkeeper, staying with them until 1982, when he was called up for military service in Belgium. On his release, in 1984, he joined [[R.U. Saint-Gilloise|Royal Union Saint-Gilloise]] in Belgium's second division.<ref name ='BobbyBook'/><ref name ='DedonBobby'/><ref name ='weltfussball'>{{cite web | url = http://www.worldfootball.net/spieler_profil/bobby-dekeyser/ | title = Robert Dekeyser | publisher = worldfootball.net | accessdate = 16 November 2012}}</ref><ref name ='fussballdaten'>{{cite web | url = http://www.fussballdaten.de/spieler/dekeyserrobert/1992/ | title = Robert Dekeyser | language = German | publisher = fussballdaten.de | accessdate = 16 November 2012}}</ref><ref name ='rundmag'>{{cite web | url = http://www.rund-magazin.de/news/417/46/Der-Moebelwart/ | title = Der Möbelwart | language = German | publisher = Rund: Das Fußball-Magazin | date = 4 June 2008 | accessdate = 16 November 2012 | first = Christian | last = Litz}}</ref> In 1986, on the recommendation of the [[FC Bayern Munich]] goalkeeper [[Jean-Marie Pfaff]], Dekeyser was brought in as a replacement for the team's reserve keeper, who was sidelined with a long-term injury. A year later he was transferred to another [[Bundesliga]] team, [[1. FC Nürnberg]], where he continued to serve as reserve goalkeeper.<ref name ='BobbyBook'/><ref name ='DedonBobby'/><ref name ='weltfussball'/><ref name ='fussballdaten'/><ref name ='rundmag'/>
After a season at Belgium's first-division [[KRC Genk]], Dekeyser transferred in 1989 to [[TSV 1860 München]], where he served as starting goalkeeper.<ref name ='BobbyBook'/><ref name ='DedonBobby'/><ref name ='weltfussball'/><ref name ='fussballdaten'/><ref name ='rundmag'/> In his sixteenth appearance for the team, he was seriously injured by an elbow blow to the face and spent several weeks in hospital. While in hospital, he learned from the newspapers that he had been replaced as goalkeeper.<ref name ='BobbyBook'/><ref name ='DedonBobby'/><ref name ='Welt'/><ref name ='rundmag'/> Despite his anger at the manner of his dismissal, Dekeyser was persuaded to make a three-game comeback for 1860 Munich when the replacement goalkeeper himself was injured.<ref name ='BobbyBook'/><ref name ='DedonBobby'/><ref name ='Welt'/> He describes these as the "best three games of my career".<ref name ='BobbyBook'/><ref name ='DedonBobby'/><ref name ='Welt'/> Although numerous offers from first and second division teams followed, he retired from professional football at the end of the 1990–1991 season.<ref name ='BobbyBook'/><ref name ='DedonBobby'/><ref name ='Welt'/><ref name ='rundmag'/>
==Business career== Dekeyser founded his first company, DEDON, while recovering from a facial injury in hospital.<ref name ='BobbyBook'/><ref name ='DedonBobby'/><ref name ='Welt'/> He readily admits that he had no business plan or clear idea of what DEDON would do or sell.<ref name ='BobbyBook'/><ref name ='DedonBobby'/> His motivation was "to have fun working with family and friends", which he has since described as a motto of the company.<ref name ='DedonBobby'/><ref name ='Welt'/> DEDON's first products were hand-painted [[ski]]s, 80 pairs of which were sold, 50 of them later returned. It was only after a stint selling [[raffia]] [[giraffes]] imported from [[Madagascar]] that the company changed its focus to [[outdoor furniture]].<ref name ='BobbyBook'/><ref name ='DedonBobby'/><ref name ='rundmag'/>
In the late 1980s Dekeyser first began to develop his idea of an "outdoor living room", furnished with the attention to comfort, quality and aesthetics usually reserved for indoor living rooms.<ref name ='BobbyBook'/><ref name ='DedonBobby'/> Following his retirement from professional soccer, he worked closely with his uncle, an [[engineer]] and expert at [[plastics]] [[extrusion]], to create a durable, weather-resistant [[synthetic fiber]] (known today as DEDON Fiber) with a natural look and feel.<ref name ='BobbyBook'/><ref name ='DedonBobby'/> Unsure of how to take his idea of the "outdoor living room" further, however, he put it on hold.<ref name ='DedonBobby'/>
Then during a visit to the [[Imm Cologne|Cologne furniture fair]] in 1991, Dekeyser met a furniture manufacturer from [[Cebu]], a Philippine island known for the craftsmanship of its [[Weaving|weavers]].<ref name ='BobbyBook'/><ref name ='DedonBobby'/><ref name ='DedonStory'>{{cite web | url = http://www.dedon.de/en/company/the-dedon-story.html | title = The DEDON Story | publisher = DEDON | accessdate = 17 November 2012}}</ref><ref name ='PhilStar2'>{{cite web | url = http://www.philstar.com/Article.aspx?articleId=365814 | archive-url = https://archive.is/20130131105305/http://www.philstar.com/Article.aspx?articleId=365814 | dead-url = yes | archive-date = 31 January 2013 | title = DEDON Furniture: From Cebu to the World… In Style | publisher = The Philippine Star | date = 29 October 2006 | accessdate = 17 November 2012 | first = Doreen G. | last = Yu}}</ref> The manufacturer agreed to help him produce woven [[rattan]] furniture using DEDON Fiber. Soon thereafter Dekeyser moved his family to Cebu where he spent six months developing DEDON's first woven products.<ref name ='BobbyBook'/><ref name ='DedonBobby'/><ref name ='DedonStory'/><ref name ='PhilStar2'/><ref name ='Real'>{{cite web | url =http://realallthingsrealestate.com/2011/06/dedon-outdoor-furniture-michael-bush/ | title = DEDON Outdoor Furniture | publisher = REAL Magazine | date = 20 June 2011 | accessdate = 17 November 2012 | first = Michael | last = Bush}}</ref> Upon returning to Germany he and his wife, Ann-Kathrin, purchased an old farm on [[Lüneburg]] Heath, close to [[Port of Hamburg|Hamburg Harbor]], where DEDON furniture would then be shipped from the Philippines.<ref name ='BobbyBook'/><ref name ='DedonBobby'/><ref name ='Real'/>
In its first decade the company, which consisted of a small group of family and friends sharing business duties and chores on the farm, grew slowly.<ref name ='BobbyBook'/><ref name ='DedonBobby'/><ref name ='DedonStory'/> A converted chicken coop served as Dekeyser's office.<ref name ='BobbyBook'/><ref>{{cite web | url = http://robbreport.com/Home-Taking-It-Outside.aspx | title = Home: Taking It Outside | publisher = RobbReport | date = 1 July 2008 | accessdate = 17 November 2012 | first = Jorge S. | last = Arango}}</ref> Furniture deliveries were stored in the barn.<ref name ='BobbyBook'/><ref name ='DedonBobby'/> In 2000 DEDON opened its own production facility on Cebu so as to better control the design and quality of its furniture.<ref name ='DedonBobby'/><ref name ='DedonStory'/> This, along with the adoption of powder-coated [[aluminum]] frames, the introduction of more contemporary designs, and the development of innovative marketing campaigns, helped DEDON to grow rapidly.<ref name ='DedonBobby'/><ref name ='PhilStar2'/> Over the next five years, sales increased by more than 1,300 percent.<ref name ='DW'/><ref name ='Tagesspiegel'>{{cite web | url = http://www.tagesspiegel.de/zeitung/das-bobby-prinzip/625784.html | title = Das Bobby-Prinzip |trans-title=The Bobby Principle | language = German | publisher = Der Taggesspiegel | date = 20 July 2005 | accessdate = 17 November 2012 | first = Stephan | last = Krücken}}</ref> Within eight years, the Cebu staff expanded from seven to 3,600 employees.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://zeelifestylecebu.com/a-journey-to-paradise/ | title = A Journey to Paradise | publisher = zee Lifestyle | date = 9 May 2012 | accessdate = 17 November 2012 | first = Melo | last = Esguerra}}</ref>
In 2004 Dekeyser moved the company headquarters to the outskirts of Lüneburg.<ref name ='BobbyBook'/><ref name ='DedonBobby'/><ref name ='DedonStory'/><ref name ='Tagesspiegel'/> The headquarters, which included a facility for the production of DEDON Fiber, received media attention in Germany for their relaxed, family-like atmosphere and the many perks employees enjoyed, including [[billiards]], [[yoga]], [[sauna]], [[gym]] and a [[chef]].<ref name ='DedonStory'/><ref name ='Tagesspiegel'/><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.brandeins.de/magazin/zuhoeren-statt-zutexten/die-firma-die-familie-das-leben.html | title = Die Firma Die Familie Das Leben |trans-title=The Company as Loving Family | language = German | publisher = brand eins | date = June 2005 | accessdate = 17 November 2012 | first = Christian | last = Litz}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.zeit.de/online/2006/01/run_dekeyser/ | title = Sessel für Ballack|trans-title=Chairs for Ballack | language = German | publisher = Die Zeit | date = 1 April 2006 | accessdate = 16 November 2012 | first = Christian | last = Litz}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.ihk-lueneburg.de/service/unternehmen/redaktion_vor_ort/Archiv/Firmenportraits_2011/1564744/Dedon_Okt2011.html | title = DEDON: Das Familien-Unternehmen |trans-title=DEDON: The Family Enterprise | language = German | publisher = IHK Lüneburg-Wolfsburg | year = 2011 | accessdate = 17 November 2012}}</ref> Berlin's ''[[Der Tagesspiegel]]'' daily newspaper dubbed Dekeyser's emphasis on employee satisfaction, both in Germany and the Philippines, "The Bobby Principle".<ref name ='Tagesspiegel'/>
In 2006 Dekeyser sold a 49 percent stake in DEDON to a US-based private equity firm but soon regretted the sale.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.juve.de/nachrichten/deals/2009/09/dekeyser-kauft-dedon-zurueck/ | title = Dekeyser kauft Dedon zurück |trans-title=Dekeyser buys Dedon back | language = German | publisher = JUVE | date = 29 September 2009 | accessdate = 17 November 2012}}</ref><ref name ='Build'>{{cite web | url = http://www.build-magazin.com/index.php/interviewpartner2010/items/bobby-dekeyser.html | title = Bobby Dekeyser: Geschichten Erzählen |trans-title=Bobby Dekeyser: Telling his Story | language = German | publisher = build | date = March 2010 | accessdate = 17 November 2012 | first1 = Ralf F. | last1 = Broekman | first2 = Leif | last2 = Hallerbach}}</ref> The "friendly atmosphere" of the company was being replaced by a focus on "money and numbers," he later explained.<ref name ='Interview'/> With the financial help of investor Daniel Borer, a Swiss physician, who assumed a minority interest in DEDON in 2009, Dekeyser was able to pay back the bank loans the private equity company had left behind.<ref name ='Welt'/><ref name ='Build'/><ref name ='Interview'>{{cite web | url = http://www.interviewmagazine.com/culture/bringing-outdoor-sexy-back/# | title = Bringing Outdoor Sexy Back | publisher = Interview | date = June 2010 | accessdate = 17 November 2012 | first = Jesse | last = Ashlock}}</ref>
After the buyback, Dekeyser took steps to restore DEDON's atmosphere and values.<ref name ='Interview'/> He also sought to revitalize the brand's communication, releasing photography campaigns, short films and a limited-edition book all shot by American fashion photographer [[Bruce Weber (photographer)|Bruce Weber]], whom Dekeyser has described as "very much on our wavelength".<ref>{{cite journal | title = Camp DEDON | first = Matthias | last = Ehiert | journal = Architectural Digest | date = May 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.whitewallmag.com/2010/06/24/coming-home/ | title = Coming Home | publisher = Whitewall Magazine | date = 24 June 2010 | accessdate = 18 November 2012 | first = Elizabeth | last = Weiner}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.yatzer.com/Coming-Home-Bruce-Weber-for-DEDON | title = Coming Home: Bruce Weber for DEDON | publisher = Yatzer | date = 14 June 2010 | accessdate = 18 November 2012 | first = Marcia | last = Argyriades}}</ref> Other communications initiatives included the launch of the DEDON Tour du Monde catalog shoot, described as an ongoing, around-the-world journey to discover "unique places and moments under the open skies".<ref name ='Tour'>{{cite web | url = http://www.dedon.de/de/blogazine/posts/tour-du-monde/its-time-for-the-dedon-tour-du-monde.html | title = What is the DEDON Tour du Monde? | publisher = DEDON: Blogazine | date = 16 February 2010 | accessdate = 18 November 2012 | first = Alex | last = Marashian}}</ref> By spring 2012 the Tour du Monde included stops in [[Kenya]], [[India]], [[Thailand]], [[Mexico]], [[South Africa]], the [[Seychelles]], [[New York City]], [[Megève]] in [[France]] and the Philippine island of [[Siargao]].<ref name ='Tour'/><ref>{{cite news | title = Dem Wohlgefühl verflechtet |trans-title=Interweaving Well-being | publisher = ICON | date = September 2010 | pages = 52–53}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.dedon.de/de/blogazine/posts/tour-du-monde/dedon-tour-du-monde-a-never-ending-story.html | title = EDON Tour du Monde: A Never Ending Story | publisher = DEDON: Blogazine | date = 31 August 2010 | accessdate = 18 November 2012 | first = Alex | last = Marashian}}</ref>
Dekeyser established relationships with several new designers after the buyback, most notably with [[Philippe Starck]], who launched ''Play'', his first collection for DEDON, at the 2010 [[Milan Furniture Fair]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.dedon.de/en/blogazine/posts/collection/philippe-starck-play-with-dedon.html | title = Collections: Philippe Starck — Play With DEDON | publisher = DEDON: Blogazine | date = 14 April 2010 | accessdate = 18 November 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://viacomit.net/2010/04/29/dedon-x-starck/ | title = DEDON x Starck | publisher = Via Com It | date = 29 April 2010 | accessdate = 18 November 2012}}</ref> In a promotional video made at the time, Starck is quoted as saying "Everybody loves Bobby".<ref>{{cite video | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=86bL9ndsgm0 | title = DEDON: Play by Philippe Starck interview | date = 9 November 2011 | accessdate = 18 November 2012}}</ref> Other designers associated with Dekeyser include [[Jean-Marie Massaud]] and Stephen Burks, the latter of whom appeared in a video with Dekeyser to promote the launch of his ''Dala'' collection for DEDON at the 2012 Milan Furniture Fair.<ref>{{cite video | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ECJqyvJ5NPs/ | title = DALA — The Mission | date = 17 April 2012 | accessdate = 18 November 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.dedon.de/en/blogazine/posts/dedon-designers/design-talk-jean-marie-massaud.html | title = DEDON Designers — Design Talk: Jean-Marie Massaud | publisher = DEDON: Blogazine | date = 11 February 2010 | accessdate = 18 November 2012}}</ref>
In 2010, less than a year after Dekeyser's return, DEDON opened a wholly owned [[United States|US]] subsidiary, DEDON USA, followed by the launch of DEDON's first US showroom, located in the [[SoHo]] neighborhood of [[Manhattan]].<ref>{{cite news | title = Dwell Magazine | publisher = DEDON | date = April 2011 | page = 129}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.dedon.de/de/blogazine/posts/company/soho-here-we-come.html | title = SoHo — Here We Come! | publisher = DEDON: Blogazine | date = 14 December 2010 | accessdate = 18 November 2012 | first= Julia | last = Chaplin}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/25/garden/25open.html?_r=1 | title = In SoHo, a New Outpost for High-Style Outdoor Furniture | publisher = The New York Times | date = 24 November 2010 | accessdate = 18 November 2012 | first = Rima | last = Suqi}}</ref> A [[Los Angeles]] showroom was opened in early 2012.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.californiahomedesign.com/blog/2012/02/06/design-buzz-hanging-out-dedons-killer-outdoor-collection/ | title = Design Buzz: Hanging Out with DEDON's Killer Outdoor Collection | publisher = California Home + Design | date = 2 June 2012 | accessdate = 18 November 2012 | first = Kira | last = Coplin}}</ref> Due to DEDON's growing activities in the US, Dekeyser spent an increasing amount of time in New York City.<ref name ='Welt'/>
In the spring of 2012 the company opened DEDON ISLAND, a luxury resort with a "barefoot state of mind" on the Philippine island of Siargao.<ref name ='Vogue'/><ref name ='Build'/><ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.vogue.it/en/magazine/books-and-travel/2012/05/dream-makers-in-paradise/ | title = Dream makers in paradise | publisher = VOGUE Italia | date = May 2012 | accessdate = 18 November 2012 | first = Sophie | last = Djerlal | page = 78}}</ref>
After stepping back from operations in 2014, Dekeyser sold his remaining stake in DEDON in December 2016.<ref>http://www.moebelmarkt.de/beitrag/dedon-dekeyser-verkauft-seine-anteile</ref>
==Philanthropy== In 2009 Dekeyser co-founded the [[Dekeyser&Friends Foundation|''Dekeyser&Friends'']] Foundation, which is based in Geneva and with a stated purpose "to inspire young people to follow their dreams and bring about change in the world".<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.dekeyserandfriends.com/ | title = Our Mission | publisher = [[Dekeyser&Friends Foundation]] | accessdate = 18 November 2012}}</ref> Since its inception, the foundation has brought young people aged 18 to 28 together for encounters with [[Mentorship|mentors]], or 'friends', such as German Olympic double gold medalist skier [[Markus Wasmeier]] and Turkish traditional dance troupe leader Mustafa Erdoğan.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://dfacademy.org/friends/ | title = Inspire the next generation – become a D&F Friend! | publisher = D&F Academy | accessdate = 18 November 2012 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121108121244/http://dfacademy.org/friends | archivedate = 8 November 2012 | df = dmy-all }}</ref><ref name=D&F2>{{cite web | url = http://www.dekeyserandfriends.org/what-we-do/df-academy/ | title = What We Do | publisher = [[Dekeyser&Friends Foundation]] | accessdate = 18 November 2012 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121123165949/http://www.dekeyserandfriends.org/what-we-do/df-academy/ | archivedate = 23 November 2012 | df = dmy-all }}</ref>
One initiative of the foundation was the Hamburg-based ''[[D&F Academy]]'', described as a "platform where knowledgeable and inspiring personalities can pass on their experience to young people from around the world in hands-on learning projects".<ref name = D&F2/><ref name ='D&FAcademy'>{{cite web | url = http://dfacademy.org/about/about_us/ | title = About Us | publisher = D&F Academy | accessdate = 18 November 2012}}</ref> The academy's inaugural program was led by British anthropologist and environmentalist [[Jane Goodall]], its second program by the former German national team and [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] goalkeeper [[Jens Lehmann]].<ref name ='D&FAcademy'/>
One of the foundation's longest-running and most comprehensive projects is the Compostela Village Project, which began in 2009 on Cebu. This rehousing project has provided a new home to around 500 people (primarily families) who until then had been living on a dumpsite on Cebu.<ref name ='Vogue'/><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.dekeyserandfriends.org/what-we-do/philantrophy/ | title = What We Do - Philantrpoy | publisher = [[Dekeyser&Friends Foundation]] | accessdate = 18 November 2012}}</ref> So that they can build thriving and independent lives, the residents learn skills such as farming, animal husbandry, weaving, jewelry-making, and sewing.<ref name ='Vogue'/><ref>{{cite web | url = http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/156859/weaving-training-for-scavengers-held/ | title = Weaving training for scavengers held | publisher = The Philippine Daily Inquirer | date = 6 March 2012 | accessdate = 18 November 2012}}</ref>
==Personal life== While on a business trip to the Philippines in 2010, Dekeyser received the news that Ann-Kathrin, his wife of more than 20 years, was in a coma back in Germany. She died before he could make it home.<ref name ='BobbyBook'/><ref name ='Welt'/> The story serves as the prologue of ''Unverkäuflich ('Not For Sale')'', Dekeyser's autobiography, published by Ankerherz Verlag in May 2012.<ref name ='BobbyBook'/><ref name ='Welt'/> Dekeyser credits family and old friends with helping him recover after an eight-month period he describes as a "hole that could not be deeper or blacker".<ref name ='BobbyBook'/><ref name ='Welt'/>
As of 2015, he was dating American actress [[Gina Gershon]].<ref>{{cite web | url = https://pagesix.com/2015/12/21/gina-gershon-and-bobby-dekeyser-are-in-a-long-distance-relationship/ | title = Gina Gershon and Bobby Dekeyser are in a long-distance relationship | website = Page Six | date = 21 December 2015 | access-date = 15 May 2018 | first = Carlos | last = Greer}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://www.dekeyserandfriends.org/ Dekeyser & Friends] * [http://www.dedon.de/en/ DEDON] * [http://www.dedonisland.com/en/ DEDON ISLAND]
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}}

{{distinguish|Robert Lehmann}} {{Infobox person | image = | caption = |birth_name = Robert Owen Lehman | birth_date = September 29, 1891 | birth_place = [[New York City]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1969|08|09|1891|09|29}} | death_place = | residence = | nationality = United States | education = [[Hotchkiss School]] (1908)
[[Yale University]] (1913) | occupation = Banker | known_for = CEO of [[Lehman Brothers]] | religion = | networth = | children = ''with Meeker:''
--[[Robert Owen Lehman Jr.]] | spouse = Ruth S. Lamar Rumsey (divorced)
Ruth Leavitt Meeker
Lee Anz Lynn | parents = Carrie Lauer Lehman
[[Philip Lehman]] | family = | website = }} '''Robert Owen Lehman, Sr.''' (September 29, 1891 – August 9, 1969) was an [[United States|American]] banker, head of [[Lehman Brothers]] for decades, and a notable race-horse owner, art collector, and philanthropist. ==Life and career== Lehman was born to a [[American Jews|Jewish]] family in [[New York City]]. He was the son of [[Philip Lehman]] (1861–1947), son of [[Emanuel Lehman]], cofounder of [[Lehman Brothers]] [[investment bank]], and Carrie Lauer (1865–1937).[http://research.frick.org/directoryweb/browserecord.php?-action=browse&-recid=6752 The Frick Collection website: "Lehman, Philip, 1861-1947"] retrieved April 2, 2012 He graduated from [[Hotchkiss School]] in 1908{{cite web|url=http://www.hotchkiss.org/alumni/Accomplishments.aspx|title=Alumni Accomplishments|publisher=The Hotchkiss School|date=2004|accessdate=March 8, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150310133421/http://www.hotchkiss.org/alumni/Accomplishments.aspx|archivedate=March 10, 2015|df=}} and was a 1913 graduate of [[Yale University]] and member of [[Delta Kappa Epsilon]] fraternity (Phi chapter). When his father retired in 1925, "Bobbie" Lehman assumed the leadership role of the family-owned business. He took over the bank during a time when Lehman Brothers, like its competitors [[Goldman Sachs]] and [[Morgan Stanley]], was essentially a one-office firm. While sound financial principles were essential, Robert Lehman was often quoted as saying that he "bet on people." One of those people he believed in was [[Juan Trippe]] who would build [[Pan American World Airways]] into an industry powerhouse. Robert Lehman understood that to maximize Lehman Brothers' growth he needed additional investor capital. While still maintaining voting control, he was the first to invite non-family members to become partners. He understood too that the right partners could expand the company's opportunities through interlocking directorships. As such, he sold an interest in Lehman Brothers to [[John D. Hertz]] who had sold his [[Yellow Cab Company]] and [[The Hertz Corporation]] for a fortune and who sat on the board of directors of [[General Motors Corporation|General Motors]]. Under Robert Lehman, the bank concentrated on rapidly developing consumer industries with financing deals arranged in retailing, airlines, and the entertainment business notably with the Keith-Albee-Orpheum theatre group 1928 deal that sold the majority of its stock to [[Joseph P. Kennedy]] which led to the creation of [[RKO]] motion picture studios. And, when Lehman put together start-up financing for [[Paramount Pictures]], John D. Hertz would be their connection on Paramount's board. Robert Lehman guided his company through the perils of the [[Wall Street Crash of 1929|stock-market crash of 1929]] and the ensuing [[Great Depression]] of the 1930s. Post-war, he grew the company substantially, expanding to [[Paris]], [[France]] to meet the financial needs of his clients with international operations. In the process, he made himself one of the wealthiest people in the United States. ==Thoroughbred horses== A lover of horses and a [[polo]] enthusiast, Robert Lehman played on a polo team with [[W. Averell Harriman]], [[Jock Whitney]] and [[Tommy Hitchcock, Jr.]]. He was also a [[thoroughbred]] [[racehorse]] owner and breeder who had five horses compete in the [[Kentucky Derby]]. His horses, most trained by [[Ralph Kercheval|Ralph G. Kercheval]], won numerous important [[stakes race]]s including the [[Correction Handicap]] and the [[Long Island Handicap]] at [[Aqueduct Racetrack]], and the [[Bernard Baruch Handicap]] at [[Saratoga Race Course]]. ==Art collection== For six decades he built upon an art collection begun by his father in 1911 and devoted a great deal of time and energy as a long-time member of the Board of Trustees of the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]], and finally becoming the first chairman of the board at the Metropolitan in the 1960s.Lamont, Lansing. "Tom Hoving and the Met Builds", People magazine, Nov. 17, 1975. [http://people.com/archive/tom-hoving-of-the-met-builds-buys-and-makes-much-of-the-art-world-bilious-vol-4-no-20/]. The importance of his collection became such that in 1957, nearly three hundred works were used for a solo exhibit at the [[Louvre|Louvre Museum's]] [[Musée de l'Orangerie]] in the [[Tuileries Gardens]] in Paris. At that time, his was the only private American collection to be given that honor. In 1968 he received an honorary Doctor of Humane Letters from Yale University for having "enhanced the civic life, the culture, and the artistic development of our civilization." After his death in 1969, the Robert Lehman Foundation donated close to 3,000 works of art to the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Housed in the Robert Lehman Wing, which opened to the public in 1975, the museum has called it "one of the most extraordinary private art collections ever assembled in the United States". To this day, his Foundation remains active, operating the Robert Lehman Art Lecture Fund and sponsoring exhibitions in museums, both around the U.S. and worldwide. Other [[philanthropic]] activities include support for [[PBS]] television programming. The Robert Lehman Art Center at [[Brooks School]] in [[North Andover, Massachusetts|North Andover]], Massachusetts, is named in his honor. ==Personal life== Robert's first marriage—to Ruth S. (née Lamar) Rumsey (born 1902) in May 1929 in Montreal, Canada—ended in a divorce about 1931. Previous to her marriage to Robert, Ruth Lamar had been married to John Williams "Jack" Rumsey (1877-1960), who was owner of the Embassy Club (a nightclub in NYC) and president of the American Play Company (an old established literary agency located at 532 Fifth Avenue in Manhattan).[https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FA0913FC3854167A93CAA8178ED85F4D8285F9 New York Times: "Mrs. Ruth Rumsey Weds Robert Lehman; Quietly Married to New York Banker in Montreal--Couple Sail on the Olympic"] May 1929[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1917&dat=19340626&id=lNBKAAAAIBAJ&sjid=sOkMAAAAIBAJ&pg=2185,6939898 Schenectady Gazette: Daughter of Ruth Bryan Owen marries Lehman cousin"] June 26, 1934 Robert's second marriage, which occurred on June 25, 1934 in Washington, D. C., was to Ruth "Kitty" (Leavitt) Meeker (1904–1984), daughter of [[William Homer Leavitt]] and [[Ruth Bryan Owen]], and granddaughter of [[United States Secretary of State]], [[William Jennings Bryan]]. Robert and Ruth Meeker had one son, cinematographer and director, [[Robin Lehman|Robert "Robin" Owen Lehman Jr.]] Meeker had three daughters from her first marriage to William Painter Meeker (1902–1983) whom she divorced in 1933: Ruth Meeker, Helen Meeker, and Kathrine Meeker.[http://salemil.angelfire.com/iBryanWilliamJennings.html History and Families of Marion County Illinois: William Jennings Bryan] retrieved April 2, 2012 Robert and Ruth Meeker's marriage also ended in divorce in 1951. Robert's third marriage—to Lee "Elena" (Anz) Lynn (1919-2006)—occurred on July 10, 1952 in New York.[https://books.google.com/books?id=Suu9yUKdA8IC&pg=PA786&lpg=PA786&dq=Ruth+Owen+Meeker&source=bl&ots=vISmUNLNJ2&sig=fXxnbQLCJBdv5yMe2IoRLCGq1oc&hl=en&sa=X&ei=42B6T7a2J9Sx0QHDypX2BQ&ved=0CEIQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=Ruth%20Owen%20Meeker&f=false Biographical Dictionary of U.S. Business Leaders By John N. Ingham] He died August 9, 1969 and is interred in [[Woodlawn Cemetery (Bronx, New York)|Woodlawn Cemetery]] in [[The Bronx]], New York City. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.metmuseum.org/en/about-the-museum/museum-departments/curatorial-departments/the-robert-lehman-collection The Robert Lehman Collection at the Metropolitan Museum of Art] *[http://libmma.contentdm.oclc.org/cdm/search/field/subjec/searchterm/Lehman,%20Robert,%201892-1969%20--%20Art%20collections/mode/exact Robert Lehman Collection catalogs] from The Metropolitan Museum of Art Libraries (available as full-text PDFs) {{Lehman family}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lehman, Robert}} [[Category:1891 births]] [[Category:1969 deaths]] [[Category:Hotchkiss School alumni]] [[Category:Yale University alumni]] [[Category:American art collectors]] [[Category:Jewish American bankers]] [[Category:American chief executives of financial services companies]] [[Category:American financiers]] [[Category:American people of German-Jewish descent]] [[Category:Philanthropists from New York (state)]] [[Category:American polo players]] [[Category:American racehorse owners and breeders]] [[Category:Businesspeople from New York City]] [[Category:Lehman Brothers people]] [[Category:Jewish American art collectors]] [[Category:Jewish philanthropists]] [[Category:People associated with the Metropolitan Museum of Art]] [[Category:Lehman family]]

{{Multiple issues|{{BLP sources|date=May 2017}}{{essay-like|date=May 2017}}}}
{{Infobox person | name = Roy Nouhra | image = Roy Raymond Nouhra.jpg | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1974|11|14}} | birth_place = Lebanon | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | nationality = | other_names = | occupation = | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = }} '''Roy Raymond Nouhra''' (November 14, 1974) is a Lebanese-Canadian businessman, investor, race car driver, and engineer. He is the founder and CEO of [[Asis Boats]] and the Co-CEO of Solico group UAE.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.entrepreneur.com/article/278859|title= Follow The Leader: Roy Nouhra, Founder And President, ASIS Boats|publisher=|accessdate=}}</ref> In 2015, he received the Entrepreneur of the Year award at Gulf Capital SME Awards.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://smeawards.meed.com/node/1201|title= Gulf Capital SME Awards|publisher=|accessdate=}}</ref>
== Early life and education == Nouhra was born in [[Lebanon]]. When he was two, his family moved out of Lebanon to [[Paris]], [[France]] because of the war in Lebanon. They lived in [[Neuilly-sur-Seine]] and Nouhra went to St Croix Neuilly School. When he was twelve, he and his mother moved to [[Montreal]], [[Canada]], where he studied at [[Collège de Montréal]], graduating in 1991.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.openpr.com/news/428840/FAST-TIMES-For-ASIS-Boats-Roy-Nouhra-driving-a-fast-car-slows-everything-down.html |title=FAST TIMES, For ASIS Boats’ Roy Nouhra, driving a fast car slows everything down|publisher=|accessdate=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://sunseaboats.com/category/people/roy-nouhra/ |title=ASIS Boats ROY NOUHRA’s love for racing}}</ref>
In 1993, Nouhra moved to the [[United States]] and joined [[George Washington University]] for Bachelors of Engineering in Civil Engineering. After graduating in 1997, he joined the Masters of Engineering Management program at the same university, which he completed in 1998.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://asisboats.com/m/2017/01/03/roy-nouhra-asis-founder-and-ceo-talks-about-worklife-balance-and-the-way-it-all-started/|title= Roy Nouhra, Asis Boats Founder and CEO Talks About Work Life Balance and the Way it All Started|publisher=|accessdate=}}</ref>
== Career == After completing his education at George Washington University, Nouhra came to the [[UAE]] and began managing his family's business, Solico UAE, along with his brother Rainier Nouhra.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gulfnews.com/business/analysis/retaining-that-personal-anchor-amid-soaring-success-1.1463268|title= Retaining that personal anchor amid soaring success|publisher=|accessdate=}}</ref>
In 2005, Nouhra founded Asis boats, a privately owned company that manufactures rigid inflatable boats, [[Rigid-hulled inflatable boat|RIBs]] and Vessels.<ref>[http://www.arabianoilandgas.com/emagazines/oe_162.php Keeping the Industry Afloat]</ref> He founded the company using the already existing know how and suppliers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.smartown.ae/kenya-navy-inspects-its-first-asis-rigid-inflatable-boat/ |title=Kenya navy inspects its first ASIS rigid inflatable boats|publisher=|accessdate=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tradearabia.com/news/BANK_293615.html|title= Asis Boats wins top Gulf Capital SME award|publisher=|accessdate=}}</ref> In 2010, Nouhra attended the OPM 42 (Owner President Management Program) in Harvard Business School and became an involved member of the HBS Alumni.
Nouhra became a board member of SWS Board Technology, a manufacturers of wakeboards and snowboards, in 2012. In 2014, he became a board member at the Sealegs International, a public company that manufactures boats in New Zealand.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sealegsrecreational.com/statutory-reporting.html |title= Statutory Reporting|publisher=|accessdate=}}</ref> He stepped down from the board in 2016. He also serves as the CEO of Solico Aluminum and Solico Trading.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com.pk/books?id=vIqhCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA114&lpg=PA114&dq=ROy+Nouhra&source=bl&ots=ophAJLOBux&sig=2Z8xfdCTUJCmCsYsTvwIyVghO2k&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwijlLqto9XSAhVBPRQKHdBzCAk4FBDoAQgsMAU#v=onepage&q=ROy%20Nouhra&f=false |title= INVESTMENT YEARBOOK 2015–2016|publisher=|accessdate=}}</ref><ref>Ebelthite, Shaun. "ASIS Amphibious RIB By Land or Sea" Yachts International,Emirates, June 2014</ref>
Nouhra is a member of Entrepreneur Organization (EO) and also serves on its local chapter board as a finance chair. EO is a network for entrepreneurs, which helps entrepreneurs learn through peer-to-peer learning and connections to experts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cpifinancial.net/features/post/38706/roy-nouhra |title=Roy Nouhra|publisher=|accessdate=}}</ref> He is also a mentor at Endeavor UAE, a non-profit that supports high-impact entrepreneurs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://eonetwork.ae/board-members/ |title= Board Members|publisher=}}</ref>
== Personal life == Nouhra has had [[Crohn's disease]] since 1999. In 2010, he went on a journey to Kilimanjaro sumit to show that a person with Crohn's disease can live a normal life.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W7DOyLy6C1M |title=Crohns Awarness by Roy R. Nouhra on Al Hurra TV|publisher=|accessdate=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PeS77LVZNzc |title=Roy Nouhra and Hassan Al- Hazeem Radio Interview with Tim Elliott|publisher=|accessdate=}}</ref> He is married to Elena Zogaib, and the couple has four children.
== Awards and honors == *2015 - Entrepreneur of the year award at Gulf Capital SME Awards.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.meed.com/news/gulf-capital-sme-awards-winners-revealed/3215724.article |title=Gulf Capital SME Awards winners revealed|accessdate=|publisher=}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == *[http://www.solicouae.com Solico UAE]

{{Infobox person |birth_name = Stephen Vargo |image = |image_size = |alt = |caption = |birth_date = |birth_place = |death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> |death_place = |body_discovered = |death_cause = |resting_place = |resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|display=inline,title}} --> |residence = |nationality = American |citizenship = |other_names = |known_for = |education = Ph.D. from University of Oklahoma |alma_mater = |employer = University of Hawaii |occupation = Professor |years_active = |home_town = |salary = |networth = |height = |weight = |title = Professor of Marketing |term = |predecessor = |successor = |boards = |spouse = |partner = |children = |parents = |relations = |callsign = |awards = |signature = |signature_alt = |website = www.sdlogic.net |footnotes = }}
'''Stephen L. Vargo, Ph.D''' is a Shidler Distinguished Professor and Professor of Marketing at the [[University of Hawai’i]] at Manoa. He has an MS degree in social psychology and a Ph.D. in Marketing. He has held visiting positions at the [[University of Maryland]], College Park the [[University of California]], Riverside, and the [[University of Auckland]]. Prior to entering academics, he had a career in entrepreneurial business and has consulted for a variety of major national, regional, and local corporations and governmental agencies.
==Research== Professor Vargo’s primary areas of research are marketing theory and thought, [[service dominant logic (marketing)]], and consumers’ evaluative reference scales. He has had articles published in the ''[[Journal of Marketing]]'', the ''[[Journal of the Academy of Marketing Science]]'', the ''[[Journal of Service Research]]'', the ''Journal of Retailing'', the ''Journal of Macromarketing'', and other major marketing journals and books, including, ''The Service Dominant Logic of Marketing: Dialog, Debate, and Directions'', which he co-edited.
==Editorial Positions== Professor Vargo currently serves on the editorial review boards of the ''Journal of Marketing'', the ''Journal of the Academy of Marketing Science'', ''Journal of Service Research'', the ''Australasian Marketing Journal'', and the ''Journal of Service Management and Service Science''. He has also served as co-editor of a special issue of the ''Journal of the Academy of Marketing Science'', as well as editor of special issues in other leading journals such as ''European Journal of Marketing'' and ''Marketing Theory''.
==Awards== Professor Vargo has been awarded the Best Article of the Year Award by the Australia and New Zealand Marketing Academy, the Harold H. Maynard Award by the [[American Marketing Association]] for ‘significant contribution to marketing theory and thought’ and the Sheth Foundation Award for ‘long-term contribution to the field of marketing’. His 2004 article with [[Robert Lusch]] in the [[Journal of Marketing]], “Evolving to a New Dominant Logic for Marketing,” is the most-cited marketing article published in the last 10 years.
== External links == * [http://www.shidler.hawaii.edu/sites/shidler.hawaii.edu/files/users/user-137/cv_vargo.pdf CV]{{Dead link|date=June 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }} * [http://www.shidler.hawaii.edu/directory/stephen-vargo/mkt University of Hawaii at Manoa, Stephen Vargo] * [http://www.sdlogic.net Service-Dominant Logic Website] * [http://www.sdlogic.net/publications.html Selected Publications on Service-Dominant Logic]
==References== * Vargo, Stephen L. and Lusch, Robert F. (2004) [http://dret.net/lectures/ssme-spring07/VargoReading-Recommended.pdf ‘Evolving to a New Dominant Logic for Marketing’], ''Journal of Marketing'' 68 (January): 1 – 17. * Vargo, Stephen L. and Lusch, Robert F. (2008) “Service-Dominant Logic: Continuing the Evolution,” Journal of the Academy of Marketing Science 36, 1-10. * Vargo, Stephen L. and Lusch, Robert F. (2011) “It's all B2B…and beyond: Toward a systems perspective of the market,” Industrial Marketing Management 40, 181-187.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Vargo, Stephen}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:University of Hawaii faculty]] [[Category:1945 births]] [[Category:American business theorists]] [[Category:Marketing theorists]] [[Category:Marketing people]]

{{expert-subject|Finance & Investment}}
A '''substitute check''' or '''cheque''', also called an '''image cash letter''' (ICL), '''clearing replacement document''' (CRD),<ref name="cdnplay">{{cite web|url=http://www.cdnpay.ca/imis15/eng/res/ns/Image_Rule_A10.aspx|title=Clearing Replacement Documents Coming This October – Amendments to Rule A10|date=n.d.|publisher=Federal Financial Institutions Examination Council|accessdate=June 6, 2013}}</ref> or '''image replacement document''' (IRD),<ref name="ffiec2">{{cite web|url=http://www.ffiec.gov/exam/check21/faq.htm#General|title=Frequently Asked Questions: 10. What is the difference between an Image Replacement Document (IRD) and a substitute check?|date=n.d.|publisher=Federal Financial Institutions Examination Council|accessdate=May 2, 2011}}</ref> is a [[negotiable instrument]] used in electronic banking systems to represent a physical paper [[cheque| cheque (check)]]. It may be wholly digital from payment initiation to [[Clearing (finance)|clearing and settlement]] or it may be a digital reproduction ([[Cheque truncation|truncation]]) of an original paper check.
==Standards and formats== Software providers have developed<ref>http://www.check21.com/virtual-check-21-processing.html</ref> "Virtual Check 21" standards within electronic banking systems which allows creation and submission of [[demand draft]] documents to the bank of deposit.
Standards may include: * Remotely created checks (RCC) * [[X9.37]] files
==Geographical significance==
===United States=== {{main | Substitute check in United States}} The beginnings of substitute checks in the United States were formalized by the [[Check 21 Act]] which came into effect in 2004.
==See also== * [[Remote deposit]] * [[Cheque truncation]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Substitute Check}} [[Category:Banking in the United States]] [[Category:Federal Reserve System]] [[Category:Negotiable instrument law]] [[Category:Cheques]] [[Category:Banking technology]] [[Category:Banking terms]]

{{COI|date=December 2015}} {{Infobox person |name = Tacy M. Byham |image = Tacy M Byham PhD New Portrait White Background April 2015.jpg |caption = CEO of DDI |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1968|3|25}} |birth_place = [[New York, New York]] |alma_mater = [[Mount Holyoke College]]
[[University of Akron]] |occupation = CEO }} '''Tacy M. Byham, Ph.D.''' (born March 25, 1968) is an American businesswoman, Industrial and Organizational Psychologist,{{Cite news|url=http://www.pittsburghmagazine.com/Pittsburgh-Magazine/October-2015/Proudly-Made-in-Pittsburgh-Inside-10-Family-Businesses/index.php?cparticle=2&siarticle=1|title=Proudly Made in Pittsburgh: Inside 10 Family Businesses|access-date=2018-06-07|language=en}} speaker, and author. She holds a Ph.D. and M.S. in Industrial/Organizational Psychology from the University of Akron.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/profiles/people/19368349-tacy-m-byham|title=Tacy Byham, Development Dimensions International Inc: Profile & Biography|website=Bloomberg|language=en|access-date=2018-06-07}} Byham is [[CEO]] of [[Development Dimensions International]] (DDI) an international human resources consultancy. She established DDI’s Executive Development Practice and led leader development programs which won a Leadership Excellence Award in 2014.{{Cite web|title = HR.com - The Human Resources Social Network|url = http://www.hr.com/en/about_us/hr_com_press_releases/winners-revealed-for-the-2014-leadership-500-excel_htrixzc3.html|website = www.hr.com|date = 2015-12-29|accessdate = 2015-12-29}} DDI was named a Leadership Company to Watch by Training Industry in 2017.{{Cite news|url=https://trainingindustry.com/top-training-companies/leadership/2017-top-leadership-training-companies/|title=2017 Top Leadership Training Companies - Training Industry|work=Training Industry|access-date=2018-06-07|language=en-US}} She has also managed the development of succession management programs and [[corporate universities]] for many organizations. As a speaker, Byham presents on innovation, managing mid-level leaders, the importance of manager support and sustainability efforts. She also advocates for the next generation of leaders around the world and focuses on mentoring and other issues facing [[women in the workforce]]. Byham gave the American Academy of Audiology Foundation lecture in 2018 in Nashville, titled, "Lead like a Girl."{{Cite web|url=https://www.audiology-worldnews.com/events/2914-lead-like-a-girl-says-tacy-m-byham-phd|title=Audiology Worldnews|website=www.audiology-worldnews.com|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-06-07}} In 2015, Byham co-authored the book, ''Your First Leadership Job'',{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/903436727|title=Your first leadership job : how catalyst leaders bring out the best in others|last=Tacy.|first=Byham,|others=Wellins, Richard S.|isbn=9781118911860|location=Hoboken, New Jersey|oclc=903436727}} with Richard Wellins, Ph.D. It contains advice and stories to help new leaders transition into a new role. She also writes articles as a Forbes Coaches Council Contributor.{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/forbescoachescouncil/people/tacybyham1/#61a24fc454b2|title=Forbes Coaches Council|last=Byham|first=Tacy|website=Forbes|language=en|access-date=2018-06-07}} == References == {{reflist}} == External links == {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Byham, Tacy M.}} [[Category:1968 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American women business executives]] [[Category:American business executives]] [[Category:Human resource management people]] [[Category:American business writers]] [[Category:Business speakers]] [[Category:Women business writers]] [[Category:20th-century American businesspeople]] [[Category:21st-century American businesspeople]] [[Category:20th-century businesswomen]] [[Category:21st-century businesswomen]] [[Category:21st-century American non-fiction writers]] [[Category:21st-century American women writers]] [[Category:Businesspeople from New York City]] [[Category:Writers from New York City]] [[Category:American women non-fiction writers]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2015}} {{Infobox magazine | title = Trend | image_file = | image_size = | image_caption = | editor = | editor_title = | frequency = Weekly | circulation = 50,000 (2014) | category =[[Business journalism|Business magazine]] | company =Verlagsgruppe NEWS | publisher =Verlagsgruppe NEWS | founded = {{start date and age|1969}} | firstdate = | finaldate = | country = [[Austria]] | based = [[Vienna]] | language =[[German language|German]] | website = [http://www.trend.at/ ''trend''] | issn = | oclc = }}
'''''Trend''''' is an [[Austria|Austrian]] weekly business magazine headquartered in [[Vienna]]. The magazine is one of the oldest publications in its category in the country.
==History and profile== ''Trend'', based in Vienna, was established in 1969 by [[Oscar Bronner]],<ref>{{cite news|title=profil|url=http://www.eurotopics.net/en/home/medienindex/media_articles/?frommedia=1572|accessdate=7 October 2013|work=Euro Topics|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131015224308/http://www.eurotopics.net/en/home/medienindex/media_articles/?frommedia=1572|archivedate=15 October 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name=dhaus>{{cite web|title=Despite Everything: The Oscar Bronner Story|url=http://deutscheshaus.as.nyu.edu/object/dh.event.DespiteEverythingTheOscarBronnerStory051513|work=Deutsches Haus|accessdate=15 October 2013}}</ref><ref name=kz>{{cite news|title=Oscar Bronner, "Standard"-Gründer, im Porträt|url=http://www.kleinezeitung.at/allgemein/tribuene/3217119/gruender-maler-demokrat.story|accessdate=15 October 2013|newspaper=Kleine Zeitung|date=13 January 2013}}</ref> being the first independent business magazine in Austria.<ref name=char>{{cite web|author=Charlotte Natmeßnig|title=Business Press in Austria|url=http://www.helsinki.fi/iehc2006/papers2/Natmessn.pdf|work=Helsinki.fi|format=Conference Paper|date=2006|accessdate=12 December 2014|}}</ref>
In 1974 ''Trend'' was sold to the [[News (publishing)|Verlagsgruppe NEWS]].<ref name=kz/><ref name=ble/> The magazine was published monthly<ref name=rustel>{{cite web|title=Media Markets: Austria Country Overview|url=http://oldtelecoms.kondrashov.ru/world/austria.html|publisher=Russian Telecom|accessdate=1 January 2015|date=August 2004}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|editor=Eric Solsten|title=Austria: A Country Study|date=1994|publisher=GPO for the Library of Congress|location=Washington|url=http://countrystudies.us/austria/127.htm|accessdate=23 March 2015}}</ref> with a size of 210 x 280 mm.<ref name=ble>{{cite web|title=Trend|url=http://www.bleispa.com/_uploads/Testate/Approfondimenti/pfdApprofondimentoT11600904app324.pdf|work=Bleispa|accessdate=15 October 2013}}</ref> It targets senior executives, [[entrepreneurs]] and decision-makers<ref name=ble/> as well as Austria's [[intelligentsia]].<ref name=char/> It is among the pioneers of [[investigative journalism]] in the country<ref name=char/> and publishes a list of Best Workplaces in Austria.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Charles J. Fombrun|title=List of Lists: A Compilation of International Corporate Reputation Ratings|journal=Corporate Reputation Review|date=2007|volume=10|issue=2|pages=144-153|url=http://www.palgrave-journals.com/crr/journal/v10/n2/pdf/1550047a.pdf|accessdate=30 December 2014}}</ref>
''Trend'' merged with its sister magazine ''[[Format (magazine)|Format]]'', another business magazine, in December 2015.<ref name=tas>{{cite news|title=Business magazines Format and Trend will merge to form one title: Trend|url=http://www.publicitas.com/global/media-news-events/news-detail/?no_cache=1&newsid=126190&title=austria-business-magazines-format-and-trend-will-merge-to-form-one-title-trend#.V_uZs5OLT6Y|accessdate=10 October 2016|work=Publicitas|date=26 November 2015}}</ref> At the same time its frequency was switched to weekly from 22 January 2016.<ref name=tas/>
==Circulation== In the mid-1980s ''Trend'' had a circulation of 72,000 copies.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Dick Hendrikse|title=It Pays to Regionalize|journal=Folio: the Magazine for Magazine Management|date=March 1986|url=https://www.questia.com/read/1G1-4155076/it-pays-to-regionalize|accessdate=16 August 2014}}{{Subscription required|via=[[Questia]]}}</ref> The monthly had a circulation of 68,000 copies in 2003.<ref name=rustel/> Its circulation was 50,000 copies in 2007.<ref>{{cite web|author=Anne Austin et. al.|title=Western Europe Market & Media Fact|url=http://conan.lib.muohio.edu/ebooks/Western_Europe_Market_MediaFact_2008/Western%20Europe%20Market%20&%20MediaFact%202008.pdf|work=ZenithOptimedia|accessdate=8 April 2015|date=2008}}</ref> The circulation of the magazine was 60,067 copies in 2010.<ref name=ble/><ref>{{cite web|title=Western Europe Media Facts. 2011 Edition|url=http://conan.lib.muohio.edu/ebooks/Western_Europe_Market_MediaFact/2011/Western%20Europe%20Market%20&%20MediaFact%202011.pdf|work=ZenithOptimedia|accessdate=6 March 2016}}</ref> It decreased to 47,248 copies during the first half of 2013.<ref>{{cite web|title=List of represented titles. Magazines|url=http://www.publicitas.com/fileadmin/uploads/common/Promotions/2013-11_Rep_List_MAGAZINES.pdf|work=Publicitas International AG|accessdate=29 October 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141030071650/http://www.publicitas.com/fileadmin/uploads/common/Promotions/2013-11_Rep_List_MAGAZINES.pdf|archivedate=30 October 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==See also== * [[List of magazines in Austria]]
==References== {{Reflist|33em}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Trend}} [[Category:1969 establishments in Austria]] [[Category:Austrian magazines]] [[Category:Business magazines]] [[Category:German-language magazines]] [[Category:Magazines established in 1969]] [[Category:Media in Vienna]] [[Category:Monthly magazines]] [[Category:Weekly magazines]]

'''Unstructured data''' (or '''unstructured information''') is information that either does not have a pre-defined [[data model]] or is not organized in a pre-defined manner. Unstructured information is typically [[plain text|text]]-heavy, but may contain data such as dates, numbers, and facts as well. This results in irregularities and [[ambiguities]] that make it difficult to understand using traditional programs as compared to data stored in fielded form in databases or [[annotation|annotated]] ([[Tag (metadata)|semantically tagged]]) in documents.
In 1998, [[Merrill Lynch]] cited a rule of thumb that somewhere around 80-90% of all potentially usable business information may originate in unstructured form.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Shilakes |first1=Christopher C. |last2=Tylman |first2=Julie |title=Enterprise Information Portals |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724175845/http://ikt.hia.no/perep/eip_ind.pdf |website=Merrill Lynch |date=16 Nov 1998}}</ref> This rule of thumb is not based on primary or any quantitative research, but nonetheless is accepted by some.<ref name="Clarabridge">{{cite web |last1=Grimes |first1=Seth |title=Unstructured Data and the 80 Percent Rule |url=http://breakthroughanalysis.com/2008/08/01/unstructured-data-and-the-80-percent-rule |website=Breakthrough Analysis - Bridgepoints |publisher=Clarabridge |date=1 August 2008}}</ref> Other sources have reported similar or higher percentages of unstructured data.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gandomi|first=Amir|last2=Haider|first2=Murtaza|date=April 2015|title=Beyond the hype: Big data concepts, methods, and analytics|url=https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ijinfomgt.2014.10.007|journal=International Journal of Information Management|volume=35|issue=2|pages=137–144|doi=10.1016/j.ijinfomgt.2014.10.007|issn=0268-4012}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ibm.com/blogs/watson/2016/05/biggest-data-challenges-might-not-even-know/|title=The biggest data challenges that you might not even know you have - Watson|date=2016-05-25|work=Watson|access-date=2018-10-02|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.datamation.com/big-data/structured-vs-unstructured-data.html|title=Structured vs. Unstructured Data|website=www.datamation.com|language=en|access-date=2018-10-02}}</ref>
IDC and EMC project that data will grow to 40 [[zettabytes]] by 2020, resulting in a 50-fold growth from the beginning of 2010.<ref name="idc">{{cite web |title=EMC News Press Release: New Digital Universe Study Reveals Big Data Gap: Less Than 1% of World's Data is Analyzed; Less Than 20% is Protected |url=http://www.emc.com/about/news/press/2012/20121211-01.htm |website=www.emc.com |publisher=EMC Corporation |date=December 2012}}</ref> More recently, IDC and Seagate predict that the global datasphere will grow to 163 zettabytes by 2025 <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.seagate.com/our-story/data-age-2025/|title=Trends {{!}} Seagate US|work=Seagate.com|access-date=2018-10-01|language=en-US}}</ref> and majority of that will be unstructured.The [[Computerworld|Computer World magazine]] states that unstructured information might account for more than 70%–80% of all data in organizations.{{ref|computerworld}}
== Background ==
The earliest research into [[business intelligence]] focused in on unstructured textual data, rather than numerical data.<ref name="History">{{cite web|last1=Grimes|first1=Seth|title=A Brief History of Text Analytics|url=http://www.b-eye-network.com/view/6311|website=B Eye Network|accessdate=June 24, 2016}}</ref> As early as 1958, [[computer science]] researchers like [[Hans Peter Luhn|H.P. Luhn]] were particularly concerned with the extraction and classification of unstructured text.<ref name="History" /> However, only since the turn of the century has the technology caught up with the research interest. In 2004, the [[SAS (software)|SAS]] Institute developed the SAS Text Miner, which uses [[Singular Value Decomposition]] (SVD) to reduce a [[Dimensional Analysis|hyper-dimensional]] textual [[space (mathematics)|space]] into smaller dimensions for significantly more efficient machine-analysis.<ref name="SVD">{{cite web|last1=Albright|first1=Russ|title=Taming Text with the SVD|url=ftp://ftp.sas.com/techsup/download/EMiner/TamingTextwiththeSVD.pdf|website=SAS|accessdate=June 24, 2016}}</ref> The mathematical and technological advances sparked by [[machine learning|machine]] textual analysis prompted a number of businesses to research applications, leading to the development of fields like [[sentiment analysis]], [[voice of the customer]] mining, and call center optimization.<ref name="Applications">{{cite web|last1=Desai|first1=Manish|title=Applications of Text Analytics|url=http://mybusinessanalytics.blogspot.com/2009/08/applications-of-text-analytics.html|website=My Business Analytics @ Blogspot|accessdate=June 24, 2016|date=2009-08-09}}</ref> The emergence of [[Big Data]] in the late 2000s led to a heightened interest in the applications of unstructured data analytics in contemporary fields such as [[predictive analytics]] and [[root cause analysis]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Chakraborty|first1=Goutam|title=Analysis of Unstructured Data: Applications of Text Analytics and Sentiment Mining|url=https://support.sas.com/resources/papers/proceedings14/1288-2014.pdf|website=SAS|accessdate=June 24, 2016}}</ref>
== Issues with terminology == The term is imprecise for several reasons: # [[Structure]], while not formally defined, can still be implied. # Data with some form of structure may still be characterized as unstructured if its structure is not helpful for the processing task at hand. # Unstructured information might have some structure ([[semi-structured data|semi-structured]]) or even be highly structured but in ways that are unanticipated or unannounced.
== Dealing with unstructured data == Techniques such as [[data mining]], [[natural language processing]] (NLP), and [[text analytics]] provide different methods to [[pattern recognition|find patterns]] in, or otherwise interpret, this information. Common techniques for structuring text usually involve manual [[Tag (metadata)|tagging with metadata]] or [[part-of-speech tagging]] for further [[text mining]]-based structuring. The [[UIMA|Unstructured Information Management Architecture]] (UIMA) standard provided a common framework for processing this information to extract meaning and create structured data about the information.<ref name = "IBMContentAnalytics">{{cite book |first1=Andreas |last1=Holzinger |first2=Christof |last2=Stocker |first3=Bernhard |last3=Ofner |first4=Gottfried |last4=Prohaska |first5=Alberto |last5=Brabenetz |first6=Rainer |last6=Hofmann-Wellenhof |year=2013 |chapter=Combining HCI, Natural Language Processing, and Knowledge Discovery – Potential of IBM Content Analytics as an Assistive Technology in the Biomedical Field |doi=10.1007/978-3-642-39146-0_2 |pages=13–24 |editor1-first=Andreas |editor1-last=Holzinger |editor2-first=Gabriella |editor2-last=Pasi |title=Human-Computer Interaction and Knowledge Discovery in Complex, Unstructured, Big Data |series=Lecture Notes in Computer Science |publisher=Springer |isbn=978-3-642-39146-0}}</ref>
Software that creates machine-processable structure can utilize the linguistic, auditory, and visual structure that exist in all forms of human communication.<ref name="IntelligentEnterprise">{{cite web |title=Structure, Models and Meaning: Is "unstructured" data merely unmodeled? |url=http://www.intelligententerprise.com/showArticle.jhtml?articleID=59301538 |website=InformationWeek |language=en |date=March 1, 2005}}</ref> Algorithms can infer this inherent structure from text, for instance, by examining word [[morphology (linguistics)|morphology]], sentence syntax, and other small- and large-scale patterns. Unstructured information can then be enriched and tagged to address ambiguities and relevancy-based techniques then used to facilitate search and discovery. Examples of "unstructured data" may include books, journals, documents, [[metadata]], [[health record]]s, [[Sound|audio]], [[video]], [[Analog device|analog data]], images, files, and unstructured text such as the body of an [[e-mail]] message, [[Web page]], or [[word-processor]] document. While the main content being conveyed does not have a defined structure, it generally comes packaged in objects (e.g. in files or documents, …) that themselves have structure and are thus a mix of structured and unstructured data, but collectively this is still referred to as "unstructured data".<ref>{{cite web |last1=Malone |first1=Robert |title=Structuring Unstructured Data |url=https://www.forbes.com/2007/04/04/teradata-solution-software-biz-logistics-cx_rm_0405data.html |website=Forbes |language=en |date=April 5, 2007}}</ref> For example, an [[HTML]] web page is tagged, but HTML mark-up typically serves solely for rendering. It does not capture the meaning or function of tagged elements in ways that support automated processing of the information content of the page. [[XHTML]] tagging does allow machine processing of elements, although it typically does not capture or convey the semantic meaning of tagged terms.
Since unstructured data commonly occurs in [[electronic document]]s, the use of a [[content management|content]] or [[document management]] system which can categorize entire documents is often preferred over data transfer and manipulation from within the documents. Document management thus provides the means to convey structure onto [[text corpus|document collections]].
[[Search engines]] have become popular tools for indexing and searching through such data, especially text.
=== Approaches in natural language processing === Specific computational workflows have been developed to impose structure upon the unstructured data contained within text documents. These workflows are generally designed to handle sets of thousands or even millions of documents, or far more than manual approaches to annotation may permit. Several of these approaches are based upon the concept of [[Online analytical processing|online analytical processing, or OLAP]], and may be supported by data models such as text cubes.<ref>{{Cite book|last=Lin|first=Cindy Xide|last2=Ding|first2=Bolin|last3=Han|first3=Jiawei|last4=Zhu|first4=Feida|last5=Zhao|first5=Bo|date=December 2008|title=Text Cube: Computing IR Measures for Multidimensional Text Database Analysis|url=https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/4781199/?reload=true|journal=2008 Eighth IEEE International Conference on Data Mining|language=en-US|publisher=IEEE|doi=10.1109/icdm.2008.135|isbn=9780769535029|citeseerx=10.1.1.215.3177}}</ref> Once document metadata is available through a data model, generating summaries of subsets of documents (i.e., cells within a text cube) may be performed with phrase-based approaches.<ref name = "textcubes">{{cite web |title=Multi-Dimensional, Phrase-Based Summarization in Text Cubes |url=http://sites.computer.org/debull/A16sept/p74.pdf |last=Tao|first=Fangbo | last2=Zhuang|first2=Honglei | last3=Yu|first3=Chi Wang| first4=Qi|last4=Wang | first5=Taylor|last5=Cassidy | first6=Lance|last6=Kaplan | first7=Clare|last7=Voss| last8=Han | first8=Jiawei | date=2016}}</ref>
=== Approaches in medicine and biomedical research === Biomedical research generates one major source of unstructured data as researchers often publish their findings in scholarly journals. Though the language in these documents is challenging to derive structural elements from (e.g., due to the complicated technical vocabulary contained within and the domain knowledge required to fully contextualize observations), the results of these activities may yield links between technical and medical studies<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Collier|first=Nigel|last2=Nazarenko|first2=Adeline|last3=Baud|first3=Robert|last4=Ruch|first4=Patrick|date=June 2006|title=Recent advances in natural language processing for biomedical applications|journal=International Journal of Medical Informatics|volume=75|issue=6|pages=413–417|doi=10.1016/j.ijmedinf.2005.06.008|issn=1386-5056|pmid=16139564}}</ref> and clues regarding new disease therapies.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gonzalez|first=Graciela H.|last2=Tahsin|first2=Tasnia|last3=Goodale|first3=Britton C.|last4=Greene|first4=Anna C.|last5=Greene|first5=Casey S.|date=January 2016|title=Recent Advances and Emerging Applications in Text and Data Mining for Biomedical Discovery|journal=Briefings in Bioinformatics|volume=17|issue=1|pages=33–42|doi=10.1093/bib/bbv087|issn=1477-4054|pmc=4719073|pmid=26420781}}</ref> Recent efforts to enforce structure upon biomedical documents include [[self-organizing map]] approaches for identifying topics among documents,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Skupin|first=André|last2=Biberstine|first2=Joseph R.|last3=Börner|first3=Katy|date=2013|title=Visualizing the topical structure of the medical sciences: a self-organizing map approach|journal=PLOS One|volume=8|issue=3|pages=e58779|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0058779|issn=1932-6203|pmc=3595294|pmid=23554924}}</ref> general-purpose [[Unsupervised learning|unsupervised algorithms]],<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kiela|first=Douwe|last2=Guo|first2=Yufan|last3=Stenius|first3=Ulla|last4=Korhonen|first4=Anna|date=2015-04-01|title=Unsupervised discovery of information structure in biomedical documents|journal=Bioinformatics|volume=31|issue=7|pages=1084–1092|doi=10.1093/bioinformatics/btu758|issn=1367-4811|pmid=25411329}}</ref> and an application of the CaseOLAP workflow<ref name = "textcubes" /> to determine associations between protein names and [[cardiovascular disease]] topics in the literature.<ref name="caseolapCV">{{Cite journal|last=Liem|first=David A.|last2=Murali|first2=Sanjana|last3=Sigdel|first3=Dibakar|last4=Shi|first4=Yu|last5=Wang|first5=Xuan|last6=Shen|first6=Jiaming|last7=Choi|first7=Howard|last8=Caufield|first8=John H.|last9=Wang|first9=Wei|last10=Ping|first10=Peipei|last11=Han|first11=Jiawei|date=Oct 1, 2018|title=Phrase mining of textual data to analyze extracellular matrix protein patterns across cardiovascular disease|journal=American Journal of Physiology. Heart and Circulatory Physiology|volume=315|issue=4|pages=H910–H924|doi=10.1152/ajpheart.00175.2018|issn=1522-1539|pmid=29775406}}</ref> CaseOLAP defines phrase-category relationships in an accurate (identifies relationships), consistent (highly reproducible), and efficient manner. This platform offers enhanced accessibility and empowers the biomedical community with phrase-mining tools for widespread biomedical research applications.<ref name="caseolapCV" />
== See also == *[[Cluster analysis|Clustering]] *[[Pattern recognition]] *[[List of text mining software]]
